video.title: Object Oriented Programming (OOP) in C++ Course
video.description:
Object Oriented Programming (OOP) is commonly used when writing code with C++. In this crash course, you will learn what OOP is and how to implement it using C++.

This course was developed by Saldina Nurak (CodeBeauty). Check out her channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/CodeBeauty

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:00:54) Introduction to OOP
⌨️ (0:03:17) Classes and objects
⌨️ (0:10:40) Access modifiers
⌨️ (0:17:26) Constructors
⌨️ (0:29:39) Encapsulation
⌨️ (0:39:50) Abstraction
⌨️ (0:52:23) Inheritance
⌨️ (1:15:43) Polymorphism
⌨️ (1:28:26) Outro
⌨️ (1:29:01) Bloopers

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

Passing *std::string* By Value is very *BAD* practise, because copy constructor of *std::string* class is called and performed *_#deep_copy_*
Allways pass *std::string* by reference like so: *_std::string &ref_* or *_const std::string &ref_*

replies.author: ॐ ࿗ The Priest of Varanasi ࿗ ॐ
replies.text: But we can call the constructor of the base class to take the input of the members of the base class. And the newly defined constructor will take the input for the new variables of the derived class.

replies.author: ॐ ࿗ The Priest of Varanasi ࿗ ॐ
replies.text: If we derive a class from some other base class and if we had defined a constructor for the base class, we also need to define a constructor for the inherited (derived) class.

topLevelComment.author: Anton Fernando
topLevelComment.text: But the bigger question is, how to decide the set of classes for a given application, architecture basically like BCE, where Boundary classes, Entry classes and Controller class help classify the problem into these set of classes. So OOP is for the most part is deriving classes and dynamic communications and class states, I think C++ power comes into properly and effectively constructing classes, methods and members, do you want a function object or a strategy class to decide the actual implementation of an algo or set of algos, while keeping in mind things like SOLID principles and cacheline friendly class layouts, and which std containers to use etc etc.  Cool video, thanks for sharing, there are so many aspects to learn about OOP,  and not to mention OOP design for testability.

topLevelComment.author: A
topLevelComment.text:
I don’t even understand why but for some reason people totally ignore the fact you can use references to make shorter and simpler class getters/setters. A function whose return type is a reference to T, which returns a class member, is a better (as in shorter) alternative.

Edit: also C++ lets you call an object’s constructor automatically when you declare it for example: std::string foo("str")
The only time you’d need to (re)specify the object’s constructor is when you’re dealing with class inheritance.

topLevelComment.text: Whats a Diff between Structure and Class ?

replies.author: Lepi Doptera
replies.text: A structure has data, a class has data and functions. You can, of course, also stuff a function pointer into a structure, which then becomes more or less equivalent to a class. The important thing for you to keep in mind is that all of this is meta-information. The compiler doesn't give a frell about it. It's all being stripped out on the way to machine code. Structures and classes are organizational tools. They make it easier for you and your fellow programmers to understand how the code is organized, but they don't change how the compiled code behaves (by much, that is, there are differences in heap and stack order of your data that are based on the class hierarchy). The problem with most OOP classes is  that they pretend to teach you programming techniques (which they don't), when in reality they are almost solely focused on team organization and software documentation.

topLevelComment.author: Alonso Calderon
topLevelComment.text: You made a great explanation of the big concepts of OOP and I understood everything you said but I still have confusion about abstraction concept. So I think abstraction is inherent to any class without the need of implementation of any contract or interface. In a natural way, a programmer who needs to use a class does not need or is interested on the details or how that class is implemented, he/she just use it through out its shared members and that's all. The only advantage that I see in using interfaces is a better organization and consistency in the inter classes' methods to implement their owns versions. So what is the point of talking about abstraction as a pillar of OOP if that is something given by default even in non OOP like procedural programming..

replies.author: Kenshin9977
replies.text:
It forces the implementation of the pure virtual method(s). It's usefull if you work on a project with a team and that the other developpers don't know every ins and outs of your class implementation.
For instance in a game I can create a class "Ennemy" and declare "pathFinding" as a pure virtual method.
Later in the development, it will force every dev that create a class that derives from the ennemy class to implement this method. That way I can count on the fact that every class that derives from Ennemy has a pathFinding method tailored to its need

replies.author: Gábor Máté
replies.text:
@Volkan Gündoğdu Let me start off by saying your intuition is awesome and you should definitely persue coding. As  you've pointed out, a setter in this case isn't a great call. 

In a realistic scenario, you'd not have a set_age(int) at all. You'd have something like increment_age(), which increments it by one and says "Happy birthday!". Her example in this case is quite bad, since something representing a person doesn't grow younger suddenly or get from 32 to retirement age.
